text: Patient: Well and… Doctor: Here’s the thing you got to take the medication. Patient: You want me to start to take a look at the Norco again or? Doctor: I think you should and just don’t let it get out of control you know, like I’d rather you take it occasionally or all the time if you need to. There’s no right or wrong on that. Family Member: It’s not that bad. Patient: I’m not that bad but there is a lot of inconsistency though. Doctor: Right but that’s your body doesn’t do well with inconsistency. It wants to know what’s coming. So if you know for example, you’re just having a hard time sleeping, then just take your Norco at night so that way you can get a good night’s rest. Patient: Okay. Doctor: If you know listen at night I’m not bothered I sleep like a rock, then take it when you first get up so that you can function. Patient: Sure. Doctor: Or you get up and it’s tolerable but now it’s the early afternoon, you still have more stuff to do, you’ve got family, you’ve got friends, there’s a barbeque, so take some, just a small amount… Patient: Sure.

text: Family Member: So he won’t get; will he – does he need nausea medication for this drug or anything? Doctor: Typically not; obviously we can, oh you know, he’s such a typical guy. But yes, Dr. ___ can prescribe that because he has a set thing because this is his program to run. So I’m just hovering nearby. Family Member: I think he was the one that actually diagnosed you with cancer when I told him to do the bone scan. Doctor: Oh my gosh! That’s been a long time then. Patient: Yes. Family Member: Yeah, because he was just going to start him on radiation and I go well - Doctor: No, he saw Dr. ___ in O____ when I was there many moons ago. Family Member: Because I told him, “His dad suffered, died from prostate cancer, could you at least do a scan on him and make sure he doesn’t have bone cancer?” And they did. Doctor: Yeah. And poof! Family Member: And bam, it showed up! Doctor: Told you you were weird. Patient: So then, yes, so then it was at that point that I went to ___ for a consult. Family Member: Uh hum, yeah.

text: Patient: But where do you draw the line as to how much you can take, you know? Well - Doctor: I don’t know. Well, that’s the problem. Patient: It didn’t affect me Doctor: Safety-wise, right now it’s only six months, you know. And there are some unexpected effects that are coming out for radium with um Zytiga because people have had, well there’s no problems with just adding the radium- Family Member: Yeah. Doctor: on top of the Zytiga. Now two/three years later, the study that they did of the combination is reporting way more factures and issues. Family Member: OOH! Doctor: So those were surprising Family Member: Yeah. Doctor: effects that nobody expected. Patient: Am I going to be sterile now? Family Member: Oh Jesus! (chuckle) Doctor: No, there’s no reason for you to. Not from the chemo.

text: Patient: You want the golden ring man. Doctor: I got ya. Patient: You want that stuff to be doing everything it’s supposed to do. Doctor: Yeah. Right. text: Family Member: Okay. Healthcare Professional: Or - Doctor: There are six drugs that have been approved by the FDA right now specifically for hormone-resistant prostate cancer. Family Member: Oh. Doctor: Two of those six are chemos. One is immunotherapy, one is a bone-targeted therapy for bone metastases and two are pills. So there are six drugs in addition to the conventional, old-fashioned hormone therapy that we only use if the cancer becomes hormone-resistant. Healthcare Professional: And there are other ones in development right now. Doctor: And there are many other ones in development, which I explained. Family Member: So are we not working towards cure are we working towards remission? Doctor: Absolutely. Family Member: Okay. Okay. Doctor: Absolutely. And again, some of these remissions are very long-lasting. Healthcare Professional: And there are people who go on hormone therapy and don’t need a second-line hormone. Like they’re in remission for fifteen years. Now he’s telling you an average but we see people who don’t need another therapy you know for many, many years. So you know it’s, you know again, I mean we don’t worry about fall –

text: Patient: No. What I- you’re looking if I can get on it. Doctor: Okay. Family Member: You’re looking at clinical trials, I guess. Doctor: Yeah. Yeah. I see. So, yeah, so that one is an option for you especially now that the PSA is going up slightly. If you want to do it, that is an option. Patient: What is it? Doctor: Okay. So what it is, is it’s a radiation, a type of radiation that you would get, but it’s tagged to something called PSMA. Family Member: Okay. With what? Doctor: P-S-M-A. Family Member: Oh. P-S-M-A. Doctor: Which is, uh, antigen that a lot of the prostate cancers produce. So what it- what that treatment does, is it attaches to that antigen on the cancer cells and releases the radiation right where the cancer is at. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: That is the idea behind it. For that, though, first, what we have to do is make sure that your cancer is actually expressing that antigen.

text: Family Member: So you can radiate? Doctor: We can radiate anywhere. Family Member: So in C___ Dr. F____ can radiate. Doctor: Dr. F____ can radiate it. If it’s needed. Now, he won't just willy nilly do it unless you have pain, or we've shown that everything about you is stable and those are the only two areas that’s acting up. Family Member: Well, that’s good to know that. I didn’t know that. Doctor: Yeah see you’re not just out there. Patient: Now I’ve got a question for you. Doctor: Yeah. Shoot. Patient: Nobody really explained to me what I will feel as this disease progresses- Doctor: Mmm. Patient: -as it changes and that I will detect the symptoms that I will. Doctor: Yeah. Well, the sheer fact that you are actually asking me that tells me that you don't have many symptoms, because people who have the symptoms, be it bone pain or just extreme fatigue or weight Loss, no appetite will tell me, “Oh man, look at all these things happening to me is because of my cancer?” So when you're curious, that means like, okay, none of this stuff is happening, which is great, but you worry about it because you think this is it, I'm gonna get bone pain. And this is it. You know, that's not the case. If you have pain in the bone, there are medicines to help or more importantly, there are techniques like radiation to help and there are other medicines that we can do to and other strategies to help the pain go away. So pain is usually what everybody worries about is number one, and then the other ones would be things like, you know, complete quality of life loss is, “I don't want to anything”

Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.displayed_text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
